conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the velocity v of the ions after passing through the velocity selector and the charge-to-mass ratio of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer.
The velocity selector consists of perpendicular electric field E (upward) and magnetic field B (outward, perpendicular to the paper).
Ions with a specific velocity v pass through undeflected, meaning the magnetic force q v B balances the electric force q E.
Equilibrium condition: q E = q v B.
Assuming q ≠ 0, we cancel q: v = E/B.
The magnitude of the velocity v is: v = E/B.
The magnetic analyzer is a quarter-circular ring with inner radius R1 and outer radius R2, and ions enter at point M and exit at point N.
The magnetic field B is uniform and directed outward (perpendicular to the paper).
Ions with charge q and mass m move in a circular path due to the Lorentz force q v B, providing the centripetal force: m v^2/R = q v B.
Solving for the charge-to-mass ratio q/m: q/m = v/(R B).
Substitute v = E/B from the velocity selector: q/m = E/(R B^2).
The deflection system has electric field E (outward perpendicular to the paper) and magnetic field B (downward), both within a cube of side L.
Ions are deflected, and the deflection angles are small (sin α ≈ tan α ≈ α, cos α ≈ 1 - 1/2 α^2).
Without fields, ions hit point O (origin). With fields, the deflection is small, and the distance from the bottom of the deflection system to the wafer is L.

The deflection angle depends on the net force, but since the problem focuses on velocity and charge-to-mass ratio from the selector and analyzer, we use the prior results, noting the deflection system refines the ion path but doesn’t alter the selected v or q/m directly.
Velocity v: From the velocity selector, v = E/B, which is independent of q and m for the selected ions.
Charge-to-mass ratio q/m: From the magnetic analyzer, q/m = v/(R B). Substituting v = E/B: q/m = E/(R B^2).
The value of R (between R1 and R2) depends on the specific design of the analyzer. Without numerical values for R, E, or B, we express the general form.
